dublin_core.dcvalue: Computer assisted navigation has a role in some orthopedic procedures It allows the surgeons to obtain real time feedback and offers the potential to decrease intra operative errors and optimize the surgical result Computer assisted navigation systems can be active or passive Active navigation systems can either perform surgical tasks or prohibit the surgeon from moving past a predefined zone Passive navigation systems provide intraoperative information which is displayed on a monitor but the surgeon is free to make any decisions he or she deems necessary This article reviews the available types of computer assisted navigation summarizes the clinical applications and reviews the results of related series using navigation and informs surgeons of the disadvantages and pitfalls of computer assisted navigation in orthopedic surgery
